_comment: FY2024 Survey Answer Schema - stores only answers, questions are in template
_savings: ~67% space reduction vs full markdown files

engagement_grid._comment: G1: Who was engaged and how

behavioral_health_assessment._comment: G3: How behavioral health needs were assessed
behavioral_health_assessment.admin_data_sources: Previous Community Health Needs Assessments, Mass.gov
behavioral_health_assessment.other_methods: Street Outreach, Syringe Service Program data
behavioral_health_assessment.barriers: Hard to find consistent data sources at a local level

existing_programs.other_methods: Networking with existing stakeholders and community partners in these spaces.

practices.name: Narcan Training for Staff at Local Businesses

planning.process: Our municipality conducted its own planning process.

treatment.barriers: Our programing has focused more on Harm Reduction and connection to resources. In the future, to address this category we will need to develop stronger ties to Treatment Centers and Healthcare Providers.

how_spent: Provide access to housing for people with OUD, including supportive housing, recovery housing, housing, rent, move-in deposits, and utilities assistance programs, training for housing providers, or recovery housing programs that integrate FDA-approved medication with other support services

Provide peer support specialists that support people in accessing OUD treatment, trauma-informed counseling and recovery support, harm reduction services, primary healthcare, or other services support for recovery across the continuum
Provide community support services, including social and legal services, to assist in deinstitutionalizing persons with OUD
Provide transportation to treatment or recovery services for persons with OUD
Support bereaved families and frontline care providers

Support the work of Emergency Medical Systems, including peer support specialists and post-overdose response teams, to connect individuals to trauma-informed treatment recovery support, harm reduction services, primary healthcare, or other appropriate services following an opioid overdose or other opioid-related adverse event

Increase availability of naloxone and other drugs that treat overdoses for first responders, overdose patients, individuals with OUD and their friends and family, schools, community-based organizations, community navigators and outreach workers, persons being released from jail or prison, or the public
Provide training and education regarding naloxone and other drugs that treat overdoses
Active outreach strategies such as the Drug Abuse Response Team model or the Post Overdose Support Team model

pregnant_parenting.barriers: Fairly specific category that we often don't encounter. Will need to become more tied into the Healthcare Institutions to make progress in this category.

additional_comments.orrf_recommendations: More money put toward housing assistance and low threshold housing stock.
